SENT.plain: OBJECTIVE: To determine the types and frequency of airway anomalies in patients with Pfeiffer syndrome
SETTING: Academic tertiary care pediatric hospital
PARTICIPANTS: Eleven patients with Pfeiffer syndrome, 6 of whom were severely affected, were identified
All were included in the study
MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES: Presence of tracheal anomalies, need for tracheotomy, and length of life
RESULTS: The 6 severely affected patients had mutations in genes that code for fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 (S351C [3 patients]; C342S [2 patients]; and W290C [1 patient])
Five of these patients were diagnosed during bronchoscopy or tracheotomy as having a congenital tracheal cartilaginous sleeve
In 1 patient, supportive care was withdrawn at 2 weeks of life, and the patient died
The remaining 5 patients required tracheotomy because of severe upper airway obstruction
Three of these patients died (at ages 9 months and 7 and 15 years)
Two are still alive at ages 23 and 18 months
CONCLUSIONS: Patients with Pfeiffer syndrome manifest significant airway pathologic conditions
Upper airway obstruction is related to midface hypoplasia and secondary nasal obstruction
Tracheal anomalies have been infrequently reported
